Articles.Content:
Webisod, webisode, whatever, wanna get something that isn't fraps or crammed full of useless/annoying "features". Looking EZVid atm, then gonna just chop the vids up or whatever, or just go through on the fly.

Would I be best off pre-recording, or live streaming/recording some how?

Been thinking about it for quite some time, since I've been a bit more confidant in how knowing how certain things might play out and what to do for my desired outcome in KSP, docking/landing whatever wherever really, been around as much as the town bike or our solar systems tea pot (Prove me wrong) and rather enjoy the game, logged 674 hours in steam on the paid for version, been playing since a few weeks before .21 came out.

Anywho, want to just start putting some stuff out there as a letsplay/career thing, plus as to kinda showcase some mods, wanna play with FAR, Enhanced Nav Ball, KAS, Proc Fair, Kethane, ScanSat, Warp, Near Future, etc etc.

Anywho, any suggestions would be lovely, also to know if anyone would be interested in such a thing, although I was going to say "Why would anyone want to watch when they can play" but really, after sitting and barely sleeping for the KerbalKon having quite a good time collectively watching someone, it's actually great fun (I don't consider the times I watched Scott Manly play "watching someone" but more, being taught what to do and what not to do and what can result in rather interesting situations (Weather it be some ridiculous contraption, or really useful tips for beginners, got my first decent docking down (First attempt) after watching him do it. Anywho.

Thanks in advance for anyone/whoever replies

For video capture, I prefer MSI Afterburner. It works well, and its free.

For what to do in your format, please, please, definitely pre-record, keep to a script, and add your comments in post-production. I can't think of anything more tedious than watching a gravity turn or menu screen while someone verbally organizes their thoughts. If you know what you want to say, and then make a video to help communicate it, the perceived quality goes way up.
Open Broadcaster Software. It's designed for streaming, but with a bit of tweaking you can get high-res video without much impact on FPS (just Google record and name). Plus it's free.
